name: Brennan conjecture
rephrased: A simply connected region in the complex plane can be mapped bijectively onto the unit disk via a conformal map, and the integral of the absolute value of the map's derivative raised to any power p (between 4/3 and 4) remains finite.
implication_form: If a simply connected open subset W of the complex plane (with at least two boundary points) admits a conformal map onto the unit disk, then the integral of |f'(z)|^p over W is finite for all p in (4/3, 4).
explained: The Brennan conjecture concerns the integrability of the derivative of conformal maps. It states that for any simply connected open subset W of the complex plane with at least two boundary points, and for any conformal map f mapping W onto the open unit disk \(\mathbb{D}\), the integral \(\int_{W} |f'(z)|^p  dA(z)\) is finite for all \(p\) satisfying \(\frac{4}{3} < p < 4\), where dA(z) denotes the area element. While J. G. Brennan proved the conjecture holds for \(\frac{4}{3} < p < 3 + \delta\) for some \(\delta > 0\), the general case \(\frac{4}{.} < p < 4\) remains unproven.
